Congress declares the need for increased efforts to address hate crimes, which are motivated by bias and aimed at spreading messages of hate to specific communities based on immutable traits. These crimes not only impact the victim and their loved ones but also harm the entire community. Federal actions against hate crimes should respect the traditional role of states and local officials in prosecuting such acts. The Federal Government must address hate crimes without infringing on the roles of State and local officials in prosecuting such acts. Data collection on hate crimes includes crimes based on gender or age prejudice. The Comptroller General of the United States, in consultation with the National Governors' Association, will select 10 jurisdictions with hate crime laws and 10 without to collect data on reported, investigated, prosecuted, and convicted hate crimes over a 12-month period. The Comptroller General of the United States, in consultation with the National Governors' Association, will select jurisdictions to collect data on hate crimes, including sentences imposed and laws under which offenders were punished. Participating jurisdictions will be reimbursed for data compilation costs. The Comptroller General and General Accounting Office will study trends within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States and the General Accounting Office will analyze data on hate crime activity nationwide, including trends by geographic region and type of crime committed. The Attorney General will develop a model statute to prosecute hate crimes and criminalize acts classified as hate crimes, including those showing evidence of prejudice. The Attorney General will develop a model statute to prosecute hate crimes and criminalize acts classified as hate crimes, including those showing evidence of prejudice. Additionally, support for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials will be provided by the Attorney General upon request. The Attorney General will establish a grant program to assist in the investigation and prosecution of hate crimes, prioritizing offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states. The Attorney General will establish a grant program to assist in the investigation and prosecution of hate crimes. States or political subdivisions applying for assistance must describe the need for the grant and certify lack of resources. The application deadline is 24 hours, and the grant amount is capped at $100,000 per case. A report is due by December 31, 2001. The Attorney General will submit a report to Congress by December 31, 2001, detailing grant applications, awards, and effectiveness. $5,000,000 is authorized for each of fiscal years 2000 and 2001. A new section is added to address interstate travel to commit hate crimes in the United States Code. A person who travels across state lines or enters Indian country to willfully injure, intimidate, or interfere with another person based on race, color, religion, or national origin, will be subject to penalties. A person who violates the law by causing bodily injury or using dangerous weapons may face fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both. In cases where death occurs or serious crimes like kidnapping or sexual abuse are involved, the penalties can include life imprisonment or even the death sentence. Interstate travel to commit hate crime can result in fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both.
